channel.title: FYP21028
channel.description: A Study on Forecasting Tropical Cyclone Properties

item.title: Project Information
item.dc:creator: fyp21028_admin
item.content:encoded:
Project title: A Study on Forecasting Tropical Cyclone Properties

Supervisor: Dr Beta C.L. Yip

Student: FONG Kwan Ching

Tropical Cyclones (TCs) are intense storms over tropical seas, a kind of which is called Typhoon, that we all know and love. The bad weather TCs cause are always annoying, in particular when you don't get a free holiday with it - what a nasty cherry fondue.

Luckily, we have forecast products by the HKO, such as the track probability forecast, which is a great reality check so we can crush our hopes in advance. This, however, is not enough, because it only tells us where the typhoons may go, but not how nasty it could get. The storm might come pretty close, but if it remained weak, it wouldn't do much damage, and vice versa. That means, a forecast for TC strike risks should be present, and it better be as intuitive as the HKO's probabilistic forecast.

This is exactly this final year project's objective:

This final year project (FYP) intends to explore the ways to evaluate the probability of a TC affecting Hong Kong and the corresponding extent of the impact.

Read the blog posts to see how!

item.title: Hello and welcome to FYP21028!
item.dc:creator: fyp21028_admin
item.content:encoded: For a brief introduction to the project background, please click here. Stay tuned for the details! :D

item.title: Project Objective
item.dc:creator: fyp21028_admin
item.content:encoded:
To quote the project plan, this project's objective is as follows:
For the general public of Hong Kong which needs an accurate and intuitive means to assess the probability of a Tropical Cyclone (TC) affecting Hong Kong, and for the TC research community which needs a new verifiable perspective to assess TC threat, the product of this project (“the Model”) is a statistical-dynamical ensemble forecast that produces separate probabilities of a TC resulting in minimal, limited, substantial levels of damage or a direct strike at Hong Kong.
It must be a lot of gobbledygook to digest. In a nutshell, a new typhoon forecast will be created and it tries to assess the chances of:
  • A typhoon or a similar storm meets the criteria of typhoon signal number 1. This will cause minimal damage.
  • It gets worse and strong winds are blowing in Hong Kong, i.e. signal number 3. This will cause some damage.
  • Rejoice (unless you're a firefighter, a security guard or a cleaning worker), the situation is bad enough for signal number 8 or plus! You can expect substantial damage.
And in addition, the chances of the storm coming right for Hong Kong are also calculated. Don't mistake it for signal number 10 - this probability doesn't say anything about the strength of the storm when it arrives. The chances will be valid for 3 days, because forecasting long into the future doesn't sound wise when you realize the world is rather chaotic. Things may change so much that they become unpredictable, so we cannot go too far. The forecast will also be "statistical-dynamical". This means that it uses a statistical method to evaluate, among other kinds of data, "dynamic data", which refers to the detailed analyses computer simulations make. We don't have the resources to make simulations of our own, so this project makes do with historical statistics. These statistics include positions and strengths of past storms and archived dynamic data. The program will model the patterns in the statistics and use them as a basis for predictions. To consider more possibilities, there will be multiple models, duct-taped together as an ensemble. The members of the ensemble will "vote", that is, their respective outputs will be combined in a "consensus", which is then used as the final forecast. The vote will be unfair though, because the models deemed more accurate will get a heavier weighting when the votes are counted. We will discuss the detailed methodology in later posts.

item.title: The Dataset (Part I): HKO Warnings Database
item.dc:creator: fyp21028_admin
item.content:encoded:
It's been a long time since I have made progress updates (which there are none) - the time spent writing word salads here is better spent developing the models themselves. In any case, it is a part of the project to update this site, so here I am. This is the first part of the series on the dataset - its collection and preparation, alongside the gruesome sea of nightmares wherein I nearly drowned. The first thing to do is to collect the data we will use in the project, and this project needs three data sources:
  1. HKO's warning signal issuance records
  2. Best track data, i.e. paths and intensities of historical tropical cyclones (TCs)
  3. Dynamical data, the meteorological analyses of the atmosphere
The one that is the "easiest" to obtain is the HKO's record database. It is directly available online, but there are no simple ways of obtaining the records except scanning the resultant webpage with a program. Because the web browser has to fetch the records somewhere from the HKO website so as to display them to you, if I could recreate such a web request in a program, then I could perhaps bypass the gore scanning through the webpage directly. When I went ahead and did that, it turns out the HKO is still relying on its old 1990s-style website underneath the well-furbished hood. The link to the actual data is this and it leads to this disgusting webpage: At that point (October) I had no idea that I could just scrape (scan) the original modern version instead and thus tried to analyze the structure of the olden webpage. And for the love of God and the hatred of Satan and his chimpanzee, the webpage was built as tables nested inside tables. A table here and a table there, none of them have unique identifiers to permit easy traversal. As a result, the Python program that extracts the table holding the data had to look like this: How beautiful. Satan's chimpanzee. Luckily the HKO (probably) would not change the implementation on their side any time soon, nor will I have to redo this step again in the near future, otherwise this code will certainly break easily and be a pain to maintain. The subsequent steps were somewhat easier. For each row in the table, I extracted the columns, clean the contents up, and then put them inside a new table (to be precise, this is a list of lists). Important precautions included:
  • Daylight savings time. Prior to 21 Oct. 1979, Hong Kong used daylight savings and the hours reported must be adjusted accordingly.
  • Messy text, e.g. unnecessary trailing whitespace.
  • I do not need the directions specified in the signal no. 8's.
After that, I had some 12 columns (variables) left, namely: The HKO identifies each TC using names (with the corresponding year, of course, since names can repeat) instead of some better identifier (N.B.: I personally don't think there is some international consensus on this matter, though - everyone has different views on whether something is a TC or not, so the ID assigning will be messy regardless), so the other data sources (best track) must also support TC names. This would go on to have some repercussions. The natural last step would be to write everything to a file. The following is the output of the program: That's all about the HKO data part. See you (hopefully) next time!

item.title: The Dataset (Part II): Best Track Data
item.dc:creator: fyp21028_admin
item.content:encoded: Last time we covered the HKO database which tells us what was a strike and what wasn't. Now let us move on to the "classical" ingredient: the best track dataset. Best track refers to the trajectories and intensities of historical tropical cyclones (TCs). There is quite the number of candidates we can choose from, since many major official meteorological institutions have one such dataset. The dataset that caught my eye in particular is that of the Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC): Apart from the data themselves, documentation about error margins, reanalyses and usage precautions are also included, even though I have never used them yet. One major drawback of this dataset is that TCs included are not referred to by names, making it ever so slightly tricky to combine it with the HKO records which do use names. Luckily, there is this IBTrACS dataset that does not just include the entire JTWC dataset, but also TC names and some other potentially useful variables (predictors, so to speak) such as wind radii. In fact, IBTrACS is a collection of best track datasets from across the globe, all in one chonky pack. After downloading the CSV version of the dataset (because I had no idea how to work with netCDF formats), the process of cleaning it began. A Python script was written for this exact purpose. A good deal of filtering was done: Firstly, the JTWC subset was selected; next, useless columns/variables (such as the TC's position as reported by other institutions) were dropped; then, the records that correspond to extratropical cyclones (not TCs) and provisional data were removed. It was at this point I noticed not all records have wind radii estimates (the radius of the circle around the TC in which winds of a certain level were expected) and minimum sea-level pressure values, and maximum sustained wind speed (VMAX as some may call it) would be the only consistent measurement of TC strength. That meant more columns could be removed in the future. The next step was to convert data types, because in CSV format everything came in strings (text), instead of numbers where appropriate. Furthermore, I want to separate month and day values from the timestamp given. It was excessively painful to tell NumPy to convert types directly - this operation is not supported because each row/record contained a mixed data type - and it had to be made a structured array instead. In any case, the finalized list of variables to keep is as follows: There are some variables that I ended up not using for the baseline models, because I wanted the dataset for the baseline models ("Baseline dataset" in short) to resemble something like the datasets people used in CLIPER or similar techniques, in order to better mimic them. I saved the processed dataset to file in the end. This is the output of the program: Until next time!

item.title: The Dataset (Part III): Dataset for Baseline Models
item.dc:creator: fyp21028_admin
item.content:encoded:
Welcome to the 3rd part of the series on the dataset used. Last time we handled the best track data from the IBTrACS dataset. To build forecasting models, we will need a dataset containing the useful variables (features/predictors) with which we infer and reason about the outcomes (labels/ground truths). In this post we will go through the steps I took to create one such dataset for the baseline models. The baseline models do not use dynamical data, i.e. the meteorological analyses are not needed, and they only take the best track data as input features. To that end, we will be using as much data from both sources (processed IBTrACS and HKO databases) as possible. A new Python script was written to do the combination step. The logic is very simple:
For each best track data record (TC position and intensity), write down whether it led to TC warning signals or not.
Remember "TC" refers to tropical cyclones, the generic superclass of typhoons and the like. The precise steps are as follows:
  1. For each record, we find which TC it is related to and grab all the records belonging to the same storm.
  2. Add the best track data for the past 24 hours (!!), sampled at 6-hour intervals just like IBTrACS to the new dataset.
  3. Using the TC name and year (season), compute the corresponding labels.
One aside about the "past 24h" part: This number was chosen so that predictions about newly formed storms could be made without having to wait for too long. This comes at a cost - if we could consider more data, e.g. up to 48 or 72 hours back, then the models would be able to pick up trends in the TC's movement better. Furthermore, this 24-hour time series selection step makes it impossible to reason about TCs that were to dissipate in the past 24 hours. The selection of the past 24 hours was not too difficult; the hard part was with calculating the true labels. To get the corresponding signal issuance instances, the program searches through the HKO database to find a TC with the same name that occurred in the same year. If the signal was to be hoisted in the next 72 hours, then it would be marked "1" (True) or "0" (False) otherwise. The problem is, again, TC naming. Before the 1970s, satellite data were practically non-existent and the position estimates were far less reliable than nowadays, therefore one set of TC positions could belong to two names - two TCs that apparently merged - or even more idiotically, the same name had spelling variations ("Babe/Babs/Charlotte/Carla" was apparently one TC in 1962). This necessitated manual checking, like so: A bit silly, eh? The computation of the label (1 or 0) for direct strike was far easier - just calculate the distance between the reported locations and Hong Kong for each such value in the next 72 hours. Another aside: this distance calculation could have been better. Currently, the distances are checked at 6h intervals, but the TC could totally pass Hong Kong at a distance <100 km within this interval, such that both positions recorded before and after the intrusion were >100 km. A better way would be to compute the distance from Hong Kong to the straight line (Just project everything onto a Cartesian plane even though the Earth is (somewhat) round, if we just calculate distances for TCs that were already within reasonable range (200km) then this should be a fine approximation. No oversized Greenlands and undersized Africas.). With that completed, the output was saved to a file. This output will be the "baseline dataset" that our baseline models work with. Here are some graphs showing how the data is like: I know, this is probably not the best way to visualize it, but you can obviously tell the dataset is not balanced: there are way more negatives than positives in each case, at least by an order of magnitude. This shows that months are correlated to the labels, except that it is not a linear relationship. Most TCs are typically weak with low wind speeds. This strange diagram is a rough scatter plot of TC tracks for those that lead to signal no. 1s. Notably, there is a huge blob of dots clustered around a certain region - that's where Hong Kong's 800km radius roughly encircles. That's all about the baseline dataset. Until next time (hopefully in a couple days)!

item.title: Baseline Model (Part I): PyTorch MLP and Change of Plans
item.dc:creator: fyp21028_admin
item.content:encoded: Welcome, time to start a new series while I'm at it. Last time, we finished the baseline dataset, and this raises the natural question: "Now what?" The most intuitive answer would be to build models to fight it. That's exactly what I'm going to do. In the original project plan, I said the baseline will be a multilayer perceptron (MLP), which was chosen for its versatility and simplicity. What is an MLP, in the first place? To begin with, the perceptron was invented in 1958 as a simple way to model things. Let's say there are some features/input variables (x_i) for it to reason about. The perceptron would take a weighted sum of their values and add a bias to it, then it would check if the result is positive. In that case, the given set of inputs will be classified as "yes" or some specific class. To update the classifications if there are mistakes, all we need to do is to adjust the weights (w_i) accordingly. A multilayer perceptron builds upon this idea by having multiple phases of weighted sums - the first phase has multiple \sum_{i} w_i x_i + b, each giving a different value, which are then summed together again. This could be understood (with a grain of salt so huge it could cover the entirety of Carthage) as chaining perceptrons one after another, so we have a simple (artificial) neural network. One problem is, if you look closely, the equation w_i x_i + b = 0 turns out to be a linear equation, that means we are actually drawing a straight line across a scatter plot of the data points so as to separate them into two sides, one side belonging to this class and the other side another. However, not all classification problems are linearly separable, i.e. a single straight line is insufficient. An example is as follows: The straight line a perceptron drew is actually at the bottom left. What if we add more layers to the network? Not very good either. This is because the chain/network of perceptrons can still be written as a single linear equation. The solution here is to add non-linearity by putting a non-linear function (such as the hyperbolic tangent) between consecutive layers. The result looks like this: Now we have two curved decision boundaries (lines to separate classes), we can easily solve this problem. Spoiler alert: The issue of linear separability will come up again in the future. But for now, let's try to make an MLP of ours and use it to model our problem. The problem is rephrased as a classification problem: For each of the given training samples in our dataset, the MLP should report whether it belongs to any of the four classes (our predictands: minimal, limited, substantial impact and direct strike) which are not mutually exclusive. This is also called a multi-label classification problem. The MLP will also report confidence scores that serve as our output probabilities, instead of deterministically reporting things like "Yes, No, No, No". The tool I used to build such an MLP was PyTorch. It was chosen because I wanted to employ GPUs on the HKU CS GPU farm. Using my prior experiences I wrote some code to do so. The program was to read the dataset, split it into three sets: training, dev/validation (to tune the models fit to the training set) and test (for benchmarking). After that, a model was defined and the training began. It was at this point I realized the baseline dataset had empty values that I forgot to take out and I almost had to start over again. With that out of the way, I let the training procedure run for some number of epochs, each time iterating through the training set once and evaluating the model on the dev set. Multiple configurations were tried, but an uncanny thing consistently happens. "Loss" is a metric that tells us how bad the model performs and it should decrease over time during the training. This is what I got when I plotted the loss values over time: The loss declined as expected, but then it shot up again. If you thought "meh, at x=150 or so you could have stopped and obtained an optimal model", then you are dead wrong. The accuracies over time look like this: This is as flat as a dead man's electrocardiogram if I've seen one. Now imagine this silly knees-bent running-about advancing behaviour repeating regardless of the model structure I chose. At this point I decided to give up on MLPs for good. According to the project plan, the first actual statistical-dynamical model would be something like decision trees. In order not to continue this senseless waste of human life, I chose to start working with decision trees instead. That will be main topic of the next post. The choice to build baseline decision trees was also sound, in that it would align the methods used for the baseline/control with the experiment. First, I build decision trees for the baseline dataset; then, I build the same things for a dataset with dynamical data; after that, I can easily identify whether the change in dataset is indeed a good idea or just a waste of time. This makes the whole experiment thing more comprehensive and convincing, in the least. So I promptly abandoned PyTorch and MLPs. That's all for today, see you next post.

item.title: Baseline Model (Part II): Decision Trees And The Like
item.dc:creator: fyp21028_admin
item.content:encoded:
Last time, we covered how PyTorch failed to make MLPs for us and why the preexisting approach for the baseline models is bad. In short, no matter how I configured them, the MLP models never seemed to fit to the data, also, the project plan's vision to use different modeling techniques for the baseline and for the actual experimental datasets was harmful because that prevents direct comparison between the datasets. Therefore, I had a change in pace and proceeded to build decision tree-based models (the original 1st option for the actual models) instead. So, what are decision trees? From the last episode, we recall that I am treating this forecasting problem as a classification (labeling, to be precise) problem, so each sample would be classified and given some class label(s). While perceptrons and MLPs figure out what belongs to which class using math, decision trees ask a series of questions. Each question is binary and the answer can only be true or false. This way, the data given can only fall into two categories (satisfying the criterion or not) upon each interrogation. If we draw out a diagram, we get something like a tree, such as: Image courtesy of XGBoost; more on XGBoost later. In the picture we check whether a family member may like a video game by considering his/her age. Further question can be asked to each separated (split) set until we perfectly classify everything in the training dataset (at the expense of future flexibility - this is called overfitting). Mathematical methods can be used to compute the best splits. One problem is that a single decision tree easily overfits and cannot generalize to perform reasonably well before unseen data. There are several ways we can deal with this, for example, we can perform pruning and trim off branches of the tree or specify a depth limit (how large the tree may get). A further solution is to use ensembles, i.e. multiple decision trees together. Random forests are a way to do so. We can plant a number of overfitting decision trees, each randomized at the beginning, and then average their results to get something more robust. We can also do boosting: plant a small tree, pick whatever mistakes it makes, then make another tree learn from them, and repeat afterwards. At some point, we will have a bunch of decision trees that perform well together. What XGBoost does is called gradient boosting, which is just boosting except that we also have a loss and a regularization term (to limit model complexity, thus culling overfitting) to optimize. So, finally, let's write some code. By the way, I have been making too little entertaining banter today. As always, I wrote a program to read the data, split them into three parts (head, gut, groin - no, I mean train, validate (dev) and test sets), prepared bookkeeping and testing utilities, and then proceeded to devise some models. The Python package of scikit-learn was used, in conjunction with XGBoost (of course, there has to be a reason why I'm bringing it up all the time). As a (presumed) good practice, I tried several variants of the methods described above, including:
  • Just one decision tree, which performed surprisingly well;
  • Extra Trees Classifier, which was even better;
  • Random Forest Classifier, which was a bit disappointing;
  • Gradient Boosting Classifier, which required some patience to fit but wasn't extremely good;
  • AdaBoost Classifier, in the name of which the Ada does not stand for this but for adaptive, and the model was rather disappointing;
  • Out of grudge, another MLP but this time in scikit-learn. Spoiler alert: it didn't work either.
  • XGBoost's classifier, which outperformed everybody else thus far;
  • And a couple variations of the XGBoost thingy.
How exactly did they perform, you may ask, but first of all I must (unfortunately) go through some technical details with you. Accuracy is not a good metric, because a naive forecaster can always say "Nah, it ain't gonna hit Hong Kong" and get 88% accuracy overall. We must be more specific - thus we primarily consider two things:
  • Recall: Given that a tropical cyclone (TC) does hit Hong Kong, how well can we predict it in advance? That is, the fraction of reported positives in all actual positives.
  • F1-score: This is the harmonic mean of the recall and the precision, which measures our false alert rates (true positives in all reported positives). It is a balanced measure of our performance.
So, let us commence forth and look at some graphs! Here are the four recall score plots: Looking good, right? It is obvious that some models are better than the others. XGBoost models consistently outperform the others. While a certain "gradient boost 400" seems to have aced direct strike, this performance could not be consistently reproduced, but XGBoost gives very similar scores every time. For F1-scores, we have: Now it is clear that XGBoost has a consistently fine and balanced performance. How do we stand, then? I have gone ahead and tried to compare the best selected models with a similar forecaster. This one is by an unofficial organization, but they do know their statistics (at least better than I do) and came up with regressional models to forecast the signal probabilities valid up to the next 6 hours. In some sense, we also predict signal probabilities (that's the truth, let's be honest), but up to 72 hours and we don't care about No.9's and No.10's. Here's a table comparing our recall and precision scores:
No.1 No.3 No.8+
Recall Precision Recall Precision Recall Precision
Theirs 0.85 0.95 0.78 0.93 0.68 0.94
Ours 0.89 0.79 0.77 0.84 0.72 0.76
At least we won in two categories. It must, of course, be noted that we use different data, different models, and predict different targets. Also, I chose the values as if we select the best forecaster for each category based on F1-score, instead of just the best recall/precision we could achieve - it is physically impossible to build a final forecaster this way. The best F1-scores are [0.83636 0.79860 0.73632 0.73118]. For your reference, below is the statistics for the final category (direct strike):
Recall Precision F1-score
Model 0.70 0.76 0.73118
All values correct to 2 d.p. unless otherwise stated/shown. All in all, "not bad" I'd say. The main difficulties this part was to fit and test the numerous candidate models and try to avoid a lengthy program (or Jupyter Notebook), both of which only required patience and caution. Next time, we will discuss the actual painful parts: operational testing (I made it forecast Typhoon Rai for fun), probability calibration and threshold selection.

item.title: Baseline Model (Part III): Still More Work On The Trees
item.dc:creator: fyp21028_admin
item.content:encoded:
Tally-ho pip-pip and Bernard's your uncle! Welcome back to the series on the baseline model. Last time we discussed how I created some splendid gradient boosting trees using XGBoost, but there was (always) still more work to do. The first and the most important thing is: how well does it work, if at all? We had some decent-looking F1-scores and precision/recall values, but do the models properly predict tropical cyclones (TCs) that they have never seen? While I could totally use the unused test set to benchmark them (and I probably should have done that), since it was December and the most exciting thing in December is an incoming TC just a week before Christmastime. The day was 16 December 2021 and I had the idea of using Typhoon Rai for a quick test to check if the baseline model was operational. It was at this moment that I realized I might want to calibrate the model's probability outputs first. Remember we are trying to forecast the probability of a certain event - thus we need sensible probabilities. Ideally, if the probability reported is 0.2, then if we get 100 identical forecasts like so, there must be 20 cases that turn out to be true. What calibration does is to scale the raw probabilities our models spit out so that we get more ideal values. And so began the procedure to calibrate the models. What we need are calibration plots, like this one: The lines indicate the distribution of probabilities reported. The closer to the dotted diagonal the line is, the better the result. Alternatively, we can use Brier scores to measure how bad our probabilities are. Therefore, my task here is was make calibration plots, calculate Brier scores, and check whether calibration was needed - if we start close to the diagonal, then there isn't much point. The calibration API in scikit-learn isn't the most usable thing ever: It returns a calibrated "estimator", but it doesn't support further scoring and benchmarking; if we unwrap the thing to take the "calibrated classifiers" inside, then they turn out to be the uncalibrated originals. Worse still, I have a multi-label classification problem, so calibration has to be done class by class (label by label). It took some Stack Overflow socializing to find a solution. So the plots were made and the checks were carried out. In general, ensemble techniques like random forests and XGBoost classifiers were able to show good performance without calibration when predicting easy targets. This happens when XGBoost tries to predict minimal impact: According to the Brier scores, calibration brought barely any improvement, so I decided to claim ignorance about calibration at least for now. For complicated targets like direct strikes, the plots devolve into something like this: I suppose I better not calibrate the model. That was one problem tackled, but there was another one. The models output probabilities (or confidence scores, so to speak), but how should they be interpreted? That is, above what threshold should we consider it a positive? For instance, maybe we should be cautious when the confidence is above, say, 30%. This threshold selection problem can be handled using math and automation (of course). As the choice of threshold affects the number of positives the model will report, precision, recall, and F1-score will be affected down the line. If we always report a "yes", then we will have 1.0 recall (actual positives always identified) but very bad precision (very high false alarm rate). An ideal threshold will balance the both and give us an optimal F1-score. By enumerating over many threshold choices, we can locate the best compromise. We can plot a precision-recall curve to visualize the compromise. Each point on the curve will be a threshold choice and its coordinates represent the precision (Y) and recall (X) scores. The curve for a single decision tree predicting direct strikes look like this: It is obvious that the point closes to the top right will be the optimal one. Here is another example, the same prediction target but with XGBoost: Much better, right? For this case, the best threshold was 0.15997 at a F1-score of 0.72956. That means, if the model gives a probability > 15.997%, then it will be more sensible to call it a strike. That was the solution to our second problem - not too tricky, only patience was needed. Now, let us go back to the beginning and try to forecast Typhoon Rai (albeit with a delay of 1 day already). The test forecast looked like this: 
For Rai, UTC time: 2021 Dec 19 0600
Will we have warning signals in the next 3 days?

Inputs:
MM DD HH 00LAT 00LON 00WIND 06LAT 06LON 06WIND 12LAT 12LON \
0 12 19 6 14.0 110.7 120 13.1 111.4 125 12.5 112.2

12WIND 18LAT 18LON 18WIND 24LAT 24LON 24WIND 
0 145 11.9 113.5 115 11.2 114.8 110

Raw probabilities:
T1: 0.01575%
T3: 0.00111%
T8-T10: 0.00114%
Direct strike: 0.00004%
Deterministic forecast (0 = no, 1= yes):
T1: 0
T3: 0
T8-T10: 0
Direct strike: 0

Cubic spline adjusted probabilities:
T1: 0.03941%
T3: 0.00394%
T8-T10: 0.00232%
Direct strike: 0.00010%
As you may know, it turned out to be very inaccurate. Also, the probabilities looked exceedingly small, even if I used splines to scale them, all of them remained far away from the thresholds. While we could totally let it be and keep the unadjusted probabilities, the inaccuracy in this case was somewhat alarming. The baseline model was unable to pick up the gradual recurvature (Northward turn) of the typhoon, which was the key reason why TC warning signals were hoisted in the end despite the month being December. Such wintertime TCs are certainly rare statistically, and their absence (or near absence) in the dataset made the model fail at predicting the right outcomes. There are two possible improvements: Include more past track data (48h instead of 24h, so the gradual turn could be identified) or teach the model to also use the atmospheric conditions in its reasoning. The second point - adding dynamical data about the atmospheric state - will be our primary focus from now on. A quick recap: the goal of this project (since two episodes ago) is to show that statistically analyzing archives of best track and dynamical data is superior than just best track. That is what I will try to do in the second semester and I will cover my exploits/misadventures in future posts. Until then, stay cheeky-breeky, I mean, healthy and fine, so when I ask you can always proudly say "I'm not dead!".

item.title: The Dataset (Part IV): Dynamical Data and Experimental Dataset
item.dc:creator: fyp21028_admin
item.content:encoded:
Finally, we can get started with the actual experiment! Let us take a break from model fitting and return to the dataset.

Data Source and Downloads

To begin with, we need to download the data first. The data source used is the NCEP FNL Reanalysis dataset, which is an archive of reanalyzed data generated from the American GFS numerical weather prediction system. We can't run one such system on our own, and if we could we don't need this FYP either, so the archives are used instead. This archive was considered especially good because of several reasons: It is easy to obtain stuff (just look at that obvious Data Access link), they frequently update the thing (it is literally updated every day!), and the data have decent quality - you get an observation at every degree latitude and longitude, 4 times a day from 1999 to 2022. Other datasets are either lacking in resolution (1.5 degree grids) or don't have data back to 1999 (spoiler alert: there is a catch). Those who outperform NCEP FNL in both regards are hard to come by and hard to download, so I passed them off as useless. NCEP FNL is also convenient that you can request a subset download. This way I could make sure I did't download irrelevant data and as such, the total download size will be smaller by orders of magnitude. The initial download size estimate was 100+ GB and I ended up needed some 5GB only. Pictured is the subset download interface. I did a brief literature review (of some 10 papers or so) to identify useful variables/features. I ended up finding quite a number of them, namely:
  1. Western North Pacific Subtropical High (WNPSH) intensity, area, and westward extension indices,
  2. Westerly index,
  3. Hong Kong surface winds,
  4. East Asia Summer Monsoon (EASM) index,
  5. Vertical wind shear: two values, between upper and lower levels, and between mid and lower layers,
  6. 200hPa level u-wind,
  7. 500hPa level winds,
  8. Relative humidity: two values, in upper and lower levels,
  9. Temperature: surface and 200hPa,
  10. Relative vorticity at 850hPa,
  11. Potential temperature at 925hPa.
The relevance and meanings of these guys will be explained later. The computation of these values will require the following variables from NCEP FNL archive:
  • Geopotential height
  • u- and v-components of wind
  • Relative humidity
  • Temperature
  • Absolute vorticity (they don't have relative)
  • Potential temperature
These were downloaded one by one using the subsetting interface you saw just now. I took whatever was in the box bounded by latitudes 55N to 8S and longitudes 53E and 164W (because no TCs useful to us will ever live outside of these ranges), ranging between 1/8/1999 00:00 and 31/12/2019 23:59. This time interval was chosen because the best track data I have ends in 2019. The atmosphere is three-dimensional and I also have to specify the vertical axis (described usually by hPa levels, with lower hPa indicating greater altitude; except a certain illegitimate-faced potential temperature), which was easy because I knew which levels I needed based on the literature. After downloading everything around the end of January, I threw them up to the GPU farm servers because they come in compressed files each containing some 18000-30000 files inside - unzipping them on my computer will probably be a gruesome thing. Might as well do the dirty tasks on the server. A quick aside! Apparently, if you want to extract .tar.gz files on a Linux computer, you say to the machine "eXtract Ze Filez!" and type "tar xzf [filename] -O [target folder]" into the terminal. If you want to see verbose output, you crank up that mad German accent and go "eXtrakt Ze Vucking Filez!" (i.e. "tar xzvf [filename]"). To compress you say "Compress Ze Vucking Filez!" in a similar fashion. For my case, I only needed "tar xvf" because they were tar files only. See also: here. Pictured: my face after having extracted the files properly, because the next step was to find a Python package that can manage them. They came in GRIB formats - a mix of GRIB1 and GRIB2 - and are traditionally managed using the NCAR Command Language (NCL) and the like. There are some modern Python packages like cfgrib and pygrib that attempt to open these files, but I could never get them to open the GRIB1 files, which I even personally verified using a hex editor they weren't corrupt - they fulfill the GRIB1 format requirements down to the bit level. Luckily, the jolly good folks maintaining NCL decided that it was getting silly to stick to it, so they started transferring it over to Python. The resulting package PyNIO was perfect, except that it wasn't compatible with my preexisting Python environment with XGBoost and everything installed. Oh well, I will just dedicate one for you.

Data Processing

So, with much ado, I eventually started processing the dynamical data. Let us go through each of the 11 aforementioned features one by one. One interesting thing is, we can actually compute these values only when we are about to merge the dynamical data with the best track data and the signal issuances. This is appealing because some of our features can only be computed when we know the TC's position as well, e.g. the vorticity value we need is an average over a 7-degree radius around the TC's centre. However, this will slow things down drastically since there will be a lot of file operations (for each 6 hour interval you get a GRIB file!), not to mention the high risk - it will be hard to debug the program as we are calculating everything in one go. The smarter alternative is to calculate all features in advance and save them to small compact files, and then reuse them when we merge. This cuts the number of file reads down to less than 20. This is also easier to manage and debug. As such I went this way. The WNPSH indices and the westerly index were calculated from 500 hPa geopotential height using formulas, which was easy enough. I could simply loop through each geopotential height GRIB file and calculate the values. The WNPSH is relevant because the TC likes to go around its outer edge (defined by the westward extension index), so its position and intensity (intensity and area indices) will be important. You can think of the WNPSH as a spiral, the ones you see when you flush your toilet, and the TC a little rubber duck floating around the edge of the spiral - of course it would be pulled around. The intensity and movement of the WNPSH are generally influenced by the westerly winds which are located at its northern side, so it will be worthwhile to also consider the westerly index. Here's a screenshot of the program's output:   What in Lord, Allah, and the Buddha's names altogether? Our data should encompass everything between 1999 and 2019, but then the program did not report anything between 1999 and 2008 being processed! That is in fact where most of our GRIB1 files should be. Let's do some quick maths: in these (roughly) 20 years, there were some 7305 days at least, so we should have some 29220 GRIB files (as shown in the num_expected thing). However, I only had 18167, the others turned out to be missing. This was a big deal, so big that the Khalifa Tower and the Pyramid of Giza added together won't be bigger than a percent of this problem: That means, in practice, I had no data before 2008, and the final experimental dataset will be around 1/3 smaller than it could have been. One thing that one can do is to find another data source to make up for it, but because of the reasons outlined at the start of this blog post, there are sadly no ways to do this - the ERA5 dataset could be tried, it probably has a higher resolution and comparable time coverage, but the time risk is high and the compatibility is unknown. So, I decided to go ahead regardless and see what would happen next. The Hong Kong surface winds and EASM index were easy to compute too. The former could not be directly calculated and the 1000 hPa level average wind speed was taken as a proxy in its stead. The procedures were the same as the geopotential height data processing, except that this time we were also looking at 850 hPa winds as well (for the EASM index). It is obvious why Hong Kong surface winds are relevant - it is directly hooked to TC warning signal issuance. The EASM supplies the western north Pacific with water vapour from the Indian Ocean and makes the Pacific Ocean a hotbed of TC activities, so it is also a relevant factor, albeit less direct. The good news is this time we only have 658 missing files. However, the damage has already been done: whichever feature with the least number of available observations will upper-bound the size of our dataset. Vertical wind shear, U200, and 500hPa winds were computed next. These followed a different pipeline, because from now on, the TC position would be needed. Therefore, the best track data processed long ago was read and the post 1999 (post 31/7/1999 to be precise) portion was sliced out, and then each of the resulting 15033 records were looped through. For each record, there is a corresponding time stamp, which can be used to locate the corresponding GRIB file. The three features rely on winds data (200, 500, 850 hPa levels). Vertical wind shear refers to the situation that the wind blowing in the upper layer goes in a different direction than that near the surface. TCs are generally a tall tower of clouds that lead up to the top of the troposphere when the TC gets mature, so if the winds up there blows in a wildly different direction, the TC's upper structure will slant off to one side, which is prohibitive for the convection going inside the tower. In short, high vertical wind shear is bad for TCs. We calculate the differences between 850 and 200 hPa and between 850 and 500 hPa respectively to get two wind shear intensity values. U200 refers to u-component of winds (i.e. going horizontal, parallel to the equator) at 200 hPa level; it is a measurement of how well the air rising through the tower of clouds can disperse when they reach the top - this "upper-level divergence" thing is good for TC growth. 500 hPa winds are separated into u- and v-components separately; these can give hints to short term movement - you can say the winds here push the tower of clouds around in the middle. Notably, the IBTrACS dataset also provides TC movement direction and speed values, so this 500 hPa wind feature may be redundant. These three are all averaged over a 7-degree radius. A total of 14875 records were properly processed, the other 158 suffered from missing data. Originally, the missing data issue was more worrying, because some TC positions were taken at hours like 9am or 3pm, but the dynamical data records were taken at noon or 6pm instead. This necessitated interpolation, e.g. by averaging between the values at noon and at 6pm to get something for 3pm. It was effective, but made the code a gruesome mess to read. Relative humidity was processed in a similar fashion. Two averages were taken: 750-800 hPa and 300-500 hPa, both in a 7-degree circle (or cylinder, to be precise). Relative humidity assesses the amount of water vapour available to the TC in the air, but this may be directly proportional to TC intensity. A sad thing happened here: there were 15165 GRIB files available and the program even dutifully browsed them all, but only 8422 records could find a match. This would have to be the upper bound of the dataset size. Temperature on the surface and at 200 hPa were calculated in the same way, but the averaging radii were different. Surface temperature was taken for 2 degrees only and up in the atmosphere 7. Surface temperature is a big deal for TC, because if the sea surface is too cold there would be insufficient water vapour (that's one of the reasons why you don't have typhoons mowing things down in the Okhotsk Sea). It would be even better if we had access to ocean heat content, which more accurately measures the TC supporting potential of the sea. Temperature at 200 hPa is relevant, because a cold-cored low-pressure area in there prohibits TC growth. Vorticity was trickier. The processing pipeline was same as before as it also needed TC positions, but the difference between absolute and relative vorticity was important. Vorticity measures the tendency of air wanting to spin in a cyclonic fashion and is arguably yet another measurement of TC intensity. Absolute vorticity is calculated with respect to a static reference frame, so the impact of the Earth's rotation is also included. This impact (professionals call it the Coriolis parameter) grows with latitude. Relative vorticity takes this term out of the equation and is the version typically used in TC research. The problem is, with the Coriolis parameter removed, the resulting vorticity values looked nowhere like actual values that you can see online, because they were much smaller than expected and could hardly be compared. Therefore, 850hPa absolute vorticity over 7 degrees was used instead. Potential temperature is the last thing to handle. This thing was a hindrance because even though I wanted it at 925 hPa level, NCEP FNL only provides sigma levels 1.0 and 0.995. Sigma levels are easy to understand: 0.995 means at that observation point, the air pressure is 99.5% that of the surface. It is useful if you want your measured variables to follow terrain outlines, but there is practically no way to recover 925 hPa data from it. As such, I had to make do with sigma level 0.995. A two-degree average was taken. Potential temperature is something that shows up often in literature, but I don't get what it is. Ok, that was quite a long article. But anyway, that was the processing done.

Merging into the Experimental Dataset

The long-awaited merging step finally occurred. It took place in early February, after all the preprocessing had been done on the GPU farm and I downloaded the outputs to my computer. I could afford to do the merging step locally, because I have already eliminated the overhead and space demands doing its prerequisites. As promised, I only need to read a few files. I largely reused the routines written for the baseline dataset - all the mistakes to commit had been committed and fixed. There would be some notable differences, though. After the testings with the XGBoost model were done, I figured that it would be interesting if we rearranged the features into something more meaningful - latitude and longitude are nice, but if we directly consider the TC's distance and bearing (azimuth) from Hong Kong, it would be more informative. Similarly, the TC speed, heading and change in intensity can all be included. I call this version of datasets "NV" (new variables). Below is a fragment of the code to fetch the new variables and put them into the new dataset. Another change would be to explicitly have the data laid out as a time series. Think about it: we have a sequence of TC positions and intensities and other stuff for the last 24 hours, and these exogenous variables influence our target, the endogenous series of warning signal statuses (e.g. hoisted or not). We are actually forecasting the changes in the endogenous variables (e.g. not hoisted - not hoisted - oops, hoisted!) in the next 72 hours using the past 24 hours, alongside a number of relevant exogenous variables. This distinction will be important when we go model the problem explicitly using time series machine learning tools in the future. What could be done is to include TC warning signal statuses and the time stamp into the dataset. This version is called "TS" (time series). Pictured are the first six features of the target dataset. The "xx" stands for "how many hours ago", i.e. there will be five sets of these guys, explicitly outlining the change of these variables over 24 hours. The NV variables will also come in five sets. To wrap it up, the experimental dataset will be TS and NV in one, with the dynamical features added. You may have doubts whether this will be beneficial. Don't worry, I got us covered: Using the TSNV version of the baseline dataset, I rebuilt the XGBoost models and turned out there was an improvement of average f1-score at around 0.05, which I figured I would gladly take. The merging step was carried out rather smoothly. Let us take a look at the results: We have a total of 6955 records available in the new experimental dataset. Mind you - there could be 15033 rows (number of best track records available) or, still better than what we ended up with, 8422 rows (as upper bounded by the dynamical features missing data count). This looked, to put it mildly, exceedingly disastrous, because we have largely lost around 2/3 of our dataset size, if we count the number of cells in the table (6955*153 = 1064115, for the baseline TSNV we have 44837*69 = 3093753, so we lost 65.6% dataset size). But in any case, this is a task done. A quick inspection of the dataset contents revealed a couple interesting (perhaps worrying too) issues: Turns out humidity values (we've got two of them) are quite similar, and u200 and u500 values are also very close. This is true for most of the cases. I think this is because of the atmosphere being more homogeneous than I assumed; and also because the 7-degree average can take in some background noise, i.e. data points lying outside of the TC's actual sphere of influence. This is presumably no problem, because mature TCs do have spheres of influence ranging up to, in extreme cases, 10 degrees in radius. Phew, I'm feeling all brain-foggy after writing this whole thing in one sitting and as one post. I hope it has been a good read.

item.title: Baseline Model (Part IV): Linear Models and Pain
item.dc:creator: fyp21028_admin
item.content:encoded:
Welcome back. Tonight on FYP21028, we investigate a new kind of models, that I call line-/curve-fitting models, or just "linear" models (the quotes are important, because not everything is linear and I'm just talking about related stuff in general).

Introduction to Linear Models

Remember the equation we saw when we talked about perceptrons? This one, I mean: It basically means we are taking a weighted sum (hence the w_i) of the input features (x_i) and see if it meets some criteria. We can further generalize this and say:
Can we treat our output as just the weighted sum of the inputs?
That is the principle behind linear models. They are called linear because if you plot it out on a graph it will look like a straight line. A classic example is linear regression, which outputs a continuous value based on its generalization of the given samples:

(Image courtesy of scikit-learn developers)

There are many linear models like this (such as the perceptron), but one thing they have in common is that they obey the principle very closely. Linear regression and other similar methods can produce a continuous output, e.g. the probabilities we want; whereas logistic regression (LogReg or Logit) can perform classification. Logit does things differently by passing the weighted sum through a logistic function, so that we can get confidence scores of whether a sample belongs to a certain class or not.

(Image courtesy of Wikimedia Commons)

The logistic function, in a sense, squishes the weighted sum into the range 0-1, so if we get zero, then we will know the sample belongs to, say, the "no signal no.8" class. Linear models are easy to create (fit) and validate, and have seen extensive use in TC forecasting too. For example, a famous forecasting method called CLIPER is basically a linear regression model trying to find future positions of TCs given past positions and other information - very much like what I'm trying to do. Linear models worked for CLIPER because there is indeed a lot of continuity in TC movement: if it wants to go straight, then it normally does so for a while, and thus it will plot on a map a straight line, which is something linear models can catch. The fun (wink wink) part is, not every aspect of TC behaviour is linear. For example, the monthly distribution of TCs is not linear - it doesn't grow or decrease with month, but rather just peaks in summer. In any case, I went ahead and performed some testing.

Linear Model Fitting (First Attempt, Without Fancy Tricks)

It is totally possible to make a logit classify TC samples as we wish, but enough time must be given so that it can (try to) adapt to the eccentricities in the data (because it isn't actually linearly separable/classifiable!). The number of iterations had to be increased to 3000 to get something remotely useful and 200 won't work. Look how it butchered the task. Recall that a model with good performance will have a PR curve stretching towards the top right corner and we aren't even close. Other classifiers include support vector machines (SVMs). They are effective and versatile, because when they try to draw a line to separate the samples into two groups (yes or no for our case, and we have 4 such pairs), it tries to make sure that the samples are kept as far away from this line as possible, so we can make a clean division between them. SVMs turned out to work slightly better than simple logits, but we can't compute probabilities from them. Regression was tried next. Linear regression failed as spectacularly as the logit, as expected, so I will not bother showing the results here. An interesting thing, however, is that k-nearest-neighbours regressor seemed to work much better than the linear models. It basically tries to group similar samples together and is by no means linear, but I included it here because it was one of the miscellaneous models that didn't deserve their separate category. Not close to the top right at all, but already somewhat closer. Nonetheless, it was just half as good as XGBoost. This is likely because the close differences between positives and negatives might not be discernible to the model, whereas decision trees can forcibly catch borderline cases.

Linear Model Fitting (Take 2: With Polynomial Features)

The failure of the linear models so far necessitated the introduction of fancy tricks. One such trick is to consider interactions between features. For example, just longitude itself cannot effectively tell us whether a TC is close to Hong Kong: Yes, it might be located exactly South of Hong Kong, but at a distance of 1000 km. If we also consider latitude, then we can make more sense out of both features at once. This can be done by calculating the product between longitude and latitude, so that they become one feature, which is hopefully linearly separable/model-able. This product trick is called "polynomial features" and is not just limited to interactions - you can compute longitude cubed if you like. I computed all polynomial features up to degree 3 (3 features as one) and there were some 1329 features (note: we started with around 18). It is possible to directly plug these into a linear model and indeed, the models I got were better than before, but not by much. The 1300 features were too many and they may contain irrelevant distractions (such as the cube of hour - how is that going to be useful?). They could also totally remain nonlinear. Leaving the second problem aside, we can tackle the first one by feature selection. There are a few ways to perform feature selection and the most obvious strategy is to compare it to our prediction targets, so that we can identify the features that truly correlate to our targets. Two measurements of correlation are available: ANOVA F-test and Mutual Information.

(Image courtesy of scikit-learn developers)

As shown in the first diagram, there seems to be a linear relationship between X_1 and Y: Y grows with X in general. F-test will give it a high score. The second diagram shows that X_2 is obviously related to Y and this time around the relationship is not linear. Mutual information will be able to give this case a high score but not so for F-test. I tried both and made them pick out the best 30 features. This is what F-test found: The isolated peaks are the features wanted, because they represent a high score. However, these features were all product between positional factors and tended to overlook intensity factors - I mean, the HKO won't always issue a signal number 1 if the TC in question is weak. This behaviour was true for all targets, indicating that F-test feature selection was probably not a good idea. How about mutual information? It took way longer to compute, so it should be able to find some goodies, right? The plot looks pretty solid - there were indeed quite a lot of hidden relationships. However, the top 30 were similar to what F-test found and did not encompass sufficient factors. With correlation-based feature selection now in the drain, the second option was to cut out the ones with low variance, i.e. features whose values were too similar. I did this using principal component analysis (PCA). It treats the input data as a blob/clouds of points in some high dimensional space, and tries to find a number of perpendicular lines (principal components) that best describe the shape of the blob. I could specify the number of principal components to take or the amount of variance to keep. It was possible to get 95% variance with just <30 principal components, but when I plugged the results through a logit, turned out more than 99% variance should be kept in order to get a meaningful linear model down the line. Conversely, with 450 principal components, the models seemed to work fine, so that would be the PCA step done. So, how well did the new models perform? Well, not quite. Here's a quick comparison:
  • Best before PCA: k nearest neighbours (KNN) regressor, average f1-score 0.43478
  • Logit using PCA-transformed data: average score 0.46772
  • Linear regression with PCA data: 0.35784
  • KNN regressor with PCA data: 0.23422 (treachery!)
At least we got some improvement, but there was still a long way to go - about a few astronomical units - primarily because we haven't considered the nonlinear nature of the data yet. Combining them in random ways makes no guarantee to fix that.

Linear Model Fitting (Trial 3 Feat. Kernel Trick)

We still have tricks up our sleeves. The kernel trick involves passing the data through a kernel, which can (hopefully) project the data to a different vector space where the data becomes easily separable. The kernel is a function and it is typically something that measures the distance between two data points (so we were arguably taking lessons from KNN, if you'd let me put it in such a sloppy way).

(Image courtesy of Shiyu Ji via Wikimedia Commons)

Pictured is a demo of the kernel trick. On the left we have linearly inseparable data - you need to draw a circle (which is, of all things, not a single straight line) to separate the points; on the right, we transformed the data into 3D and now we can put a horizontal plane in to separate the purple dots from the orange ones. There are various ways to include a kernel, and using approximations is a very useful one of them, because it is generally costly to calculate the kernels exactly. The polynomial kernel came forth as the most effective kernel choice after some tests, even though we were doing the costly and odd maneuver of calculating the polynomial features first and then plugging them through another polynomial. The results were as follows:
  • Nystroem approximation, no PCA, linear regression: average f1-score 0.36600
  • Tensor Sketch approximation, no PCA, logistic regression: about 0.435
  • Nystroem, PCA transformed, logit: 0.40031
  • Nystroem, PCA transformed, linear reg.: 0.36174
  • Nystroem, PCA, SVM regressor: 0.36404
The improvement was once more indiscernible. But don't worry, I still have one secret weapon.

Linear Model Fitting (Effort 4: Is There Life On MARS?)

Note that we have used KNN and logreg, both of which aren't really linear (the latter is linear, but not so the former). We can go one step further: what if we don't try to compute the weighted sum of the features, but a weighted sum of the transformed features instead? By transform, we aren't talking about "finding polynomial features and then use PCA or F-tests to filter some out", but rather, some simpler mathematical functions. These can be a hinge function:

(Image courtesy of Wikimedia Commons)

It is not linear, because of the max operation, and as such can possibly detect nonlinearities and fit a broken line wherever appropriate. This new strategy is called multivariate adaptive regression splines (MARS; this is a trademark by the way). The Python implementation py-earth was used (it's called Earth to avoid infringement of the trademark). Its performance was as follows:
  • No PCA, no polynomial features: average f1-score 0.37518
  • No PCA, Nystroem poly kernel approx., no poly. features: took too long to fit
It was possible that the regression splines wouldn't manage to fit to PCA-transformed data (450 features instead of just 18) even if I gave it an entire sidereal day. So, to conclude, the secret weapon was quite disappointing. But I'm not out of options yet - I will finish this blog post with the first one.

Linear Model Fitting (Attempt 5: New Datasets)

If you read through the lengthy monstrosity known as the last post, you will have heard of the term "TSNV". It is a variant of the baseline dataset (and not just the baseline actually) that incorporates two beneficial changes:
  1. The dataset was explicitly laid out as a time series (TS).
  2. New feature variables (NV) were introduced so the features would be more informative.
As a matter of fact, the change to use distance from Hong Kong to encode the TC's position makes, at least, that feature linearly separable, because unless a TC is close enough it wouldn't cause us any trouble. A small number of selected models were re-fitted using the new dataset variants (TS, NV and TSNV) and the following results were found:
  • It would be impossible to do PCA on the new datasets, because there were too many polynomial features to keep track of - it would make the computer run out of memory (OOM).
  • The performances were generally similar, except one of them:
    • TSNV logit, no PCA, no kernels: average f1-score 0.54243
That was a very significant improvement. Of course, its performance was still nowhere near XGBoost, but at least we made progress. We will make more the next time we return to linear models. But for now, let's stop at this point.

wp:comment.wp:comment_author: Experimental Models (Part III): MLPs and Pain – FYP21028
wp:comment.wp:comment_content: […] then the main source of pain was with linear models: GAMs didn’t quite work out, until we tried to generate (a subset of all possible) polynomial […]

item.title: Baseline Model (Part V): Time Series Modelling
item.dc:creator: fyp21028_admin
item.content:encoded:
Welcome back. Last time we discussed linear models (in general), this time we shall move on to something different.

Introduction to Time Series Modelling

You see, the data at hand are essentially a number of time series: Given a 24-hour time series of TC positions and intensities, the task is to predict the TC warning signal time series (or TC's distance-to-HK time series, for our fourth predictand). Then the probability that any of these signals will be hoisted in a 72-hour window can be computed from the predicted time series. This is similar to predicting whether HSI will slump given the historical statistics of the index. By harnessing this nature of the data, better models may (ostensibly) be built. Before we move on to the implementations, here are two words that were mentioned last time but will be important this time:
  • endogenous variables are the variable whose time series is what we want to predict, i.e. they are the problem itself. For our case, these will be TC warning signal status and "TC distance <= 100?" status.
  • exogenous variables are variables outside of the endogenous ones, but they have relevance/influence on the endogenous. For our case, these will be the features, which we have 10 in the TSNV variant of the baseline dataset (TSNV = time series, with new feature variable layout).
The Python library to use to implement the models is sktime, which was ever so slightly annoying to make it live comfortably with other dependencies this project would end up using. Sktime is comprehensive and encompasses a wide range of modern modelling techniques, so modern that there is barely any documentation about how they even work. These techniques fall into three general categories:
  1. Time series classification: giving a class label to a sample, which happens to be a time series. Useful for our case, as long as we can compute class confidence (probability).
  2. Time series regression: given the sample, spit out a number. Useful for our case as well, because we can directly compute the probabilities that way.
  3. Forecasting: directly predict some future values of our endogenous variables. If we could do this, it would be fantastic.
Let us go through them one by one.

Time Series Classification

Sktime provides a terrifyingly wide range of classifiers for our use. These take in the exogenous variables and matches them to the labels, which are derived from the endogenous variables (that is, the correct label to put like "signal no.3 yes" depends on the underlying variable "signal no.3 status"). There were some difficulties in getting them to work. First of all, sktime wants data to come in a different format. A very natural way to lay out our data in an electronic spreadsheet (like M$ Excel) is to use rows to represent samples/observations and columns to represent features, so we have a table with dimensions (n_samples, n_features). The columns may encode a time series together, e.g. one column for TC center latitude 12 hours ago (LAT12) and another for LAT18. What sktime wants is that we group these together and shove them into one cell, so that each row is still a sample, but the number of columns will equal the number of exogenous variables actually present (i.e. only one LAT column for all LAT00 ... LAT24). In the cell, we put in the time series as an array of values, like [LAT00, LAT12, ..., LAT18, LAT24]. In the end, the table will be 3D, with shape (n_samples, n_exogenous, time_series_length). This required an additional routine be written and executed to transform the data. The second thing is, the classifiers take ridiculous time and memory to fit. Even when allowed to left untouched overnight like a proper pizza dough, some models could not finish fitting after 24 hours. Those who got close would run out of RAM and crash. A glorious total of three models worked:
  • Time Series Forest Classifier: fits in around 10 minutes, average f1-score around 0.70
  • Multivariate Symbolic Extension: fits in 2 hours, average f1-score 0.44
  • K-Neighbours Time Series Classifier: fits in 6 hours, average f1-score 0.60
It is obvious that only the time series forest will be practical. Rather unfortunately, its performance is nowhere close to that of XGBoost, and usual decision trees can outperform it in general. Nonetheless, it is still a decent model (compared to the linear models), so I'd take it.

Time Series Regression

It is quite a shame that sktime only has one time series regression model. Luckily, it is, of all things, another time series forest. Its performance was very close to that of the classifier (f1-score 0.67), so I would take the classifier instead.

Forecasting

Although we are talking about forecasting, which is, frankly speaking, the actual goal of this project, the sktime forecasting utilities are generally more suitable for simpler tasks, such as predicting HSI without using exogenous variables. In fact, it is obvious that all experiments with direct forecasting will be a big letdown, since we are trying to predict 72 hours ahead with only 24 hours of past data in each sample. If the forecaster cannot generalize across samples, then the 45000 samples in our arsenal will be utterly useless. And that is exactly what happened. The forecasters are, in fact, modified linear models at best, but without capabilities to use the whole dataset for good (that's what regression/classification is more suitable for). A total of six forecasters were tested, by fitting a new forecaster for each training sample available, and then tallying the forecast results. The results were generally disastrous, as linear models easily outperformed them in all regards, and a naive forecaster turned out to have the best average f1-score (of less than 0.3). In any case, this was quite a misadventure. Nevertheless, I got a reasonably good classifier out of it, and something that I could play around with - I tried to forecast the last wave of covid infections in Hong Kong using sktime forecasters and constantly underforecasted. Pictured is the forecast on 20 Feb. The average among the forecasts were taken, but over the following days the official number unfolded to be somewhere above the average. I hope you enjoyed these shenanigans. That's it for now, see you next time - we will likely be talking about either Gaussian Processes or new linear models, before moving on to the super-duper experimental dataset finally getting applied to models.

item.title: Baseline Model (Part VI): Gaussian Processes
item.dc:creator: fyp21028_admin
item.content:encoded:
Howdy, my beloved yees and haws, welcome back to another episode of data science misadventures with FYP21028! Last time we had limited success with time series modelling, which we ended up using what is practically another decision tree, and this time, please brace yourselves for even less success!

Introduction to Gaussian Processes

You see, the thing that this project tries to find is a magic function or a black box that takes in data related to TCs and spits out the probabilities of it affecting Hong Kong. We can call this magical thing a "latent function", because it is hidden behind the data. Without access to this latent function itself, the best that could be done is to approximate it. This is where Gaussian Processes (GPs) come in. Each data sample is an example of what this latent function does plus some noise, e.g. y = f(x) + noise with f being the latent function. Therefore, similar inputs of x can give different results, distributed according to the rules set by f and the noise component. If we assume this distribution to be, say, Gaussian/normal, then it will be possible to estimate the mean (average) and variance of y given a fixed x. What GPs do is to further extend this logic, so that when the mean varies with different input x, there is still some way to track it. Then, ideally, the latent function f that we are looking for will be approximated using the means.

(Image courtesy of scikit-learn developers)

In the picture, we can see the latent function f in blue and the approximation in orange. The orange curve corresponds to the average whereas the vertical bars represent noise - we can, of course, explain everything as noise, but it is more worthwhile to explain them as a Gaussian distribution that morphs and changes over x. GPs are useful in several ways: the distribution allows for direct computation of probabilities, and since predictions will be similar to observed data (i.e. the former interpolates the latter), that means we can be sure that predictions will stay within reasonable ranges. So, all in all, a good idea.

GPyTorch Installation

The implementation of GPs was difficult because the dataset turned out to be too large for it to gobble in one swallow. The scikit-learn implementations of the thing simply ran out of memory (OOM). A different software package that could do the job efficiently was sought after, and before long I identified GPyTorch to be the suitable one, since it can use GPUs and is scalable (by being able to approximate the GP results instead of forcibly calculating an exact GP). The installation of this bad boy, however, was a headache. It had trouble coexisting with sktime (from last time) and when they finally managed to coexist, GPyTorch refused to use the GPU. The solution was to install sktime and PyTorch (the dependency of GPyTorch that allows it to use GPUs) into a clean environment, obtaining GPU support at the same time, before XGBoost, GPyTorch and other dependencies would be brought in. This came at a further cost, because now py-earth (implements MARS (TM) for linear models) had a conflict with something and could no longer be used. Whether MARS or GP should be used would depend on their respective performances, so I chose to wait and see.

Model Building Attempts

Because exact GPs will OOM, there were very few options when it came to building an approximate GP. To build an approximate GP, a number of "induction points" are to be provided, so that there is a basis to estimate from. This number cannot be too big, because it will OOM; but conversely it also means our approximation capacity is very limited. The other things to specify include a mean module and a covariance module, which are assumptions about the data's distribution. The RBF kernel was used for covariance because it is the suggested starting point and the mean was assumed to be a constant (think about it: we have a lot of zeros and some ones, that averages to a constant) which made sense because other configurations didn't work. The likelihood is also configurable. It allows calculation of probabilities. For our case, since the output is binary (yes vs no), Bernoulli likelihood was suitable. While GPs generally handle one output variable only, there is also the second option of making the GP multitask, i.e. make it take on all targets at once. In any case, the model and the data were then sent to the GPU where the training occurred. It was done in a similar fashion to that of the PyTorch MLP, which involves the following steps:
  • Put the input data through the model in batches
  • For each batch, calculate the loss (measures how bad a model is) and make the model update itself accordingly
  • Repeat these two steps for some number of times, preferably until the loss stops improving

Results

I think it's about time to show you a picture, so let us behold the precision recall curve for direct strike: Oopsie whoopsie, the thing doesn't work! None of the four f1-scores managed to pass 0.2. The other configuration (multitask GP) was also tried, yielding the same result. There could be several reasons behind this:
  • Wrong likelihood chosen? Good point, but other feasible options showed no difference.
  • Wrong loss function? This was likely why MLPs never worked. However, there are only 2 workable options for approximate GPs and neither worked.
  • Not enough inducing points? As many as 10,000 were used, risking OOM, but there wasn't a clear difference.
  • Wrong kernel/covariance module? There are no tutorials on how to mix and match, and covariance might not be the key to the problem.
  • Wrong mean module? Perhaps not, other alternatives failed to make any difference.
  • GPs are completely unsuitable. That is, the dataset given was rather inappropriate, so that the assumptions and methodologies of GPs became inapplicable. For instance, the complex hyperplanes the data forms could not be captured by the model, or the imbalanced nature of the data (too many negatives) skewed the mean so that predicting using the means would be nonsensical.
But in conclusion, GP proved itself to be inadequate for our problem. However, soon enough, we would find something that would work.

item.title: Baseline Model (Part VII): The Return of the MLP
item.dc:creator: fyp21028_admin
item.content:encoded:
Ladies and non-ladies, welcome back! Today we will have the second-last episode of the baseline model series. The discussion on experimental models will be very brief in comparison, because all the inner workings and pitfalls have already been covered in the baseline series. Our topic today is multilayer perceptron (MLP). For those of you who have brains bigger than a duck's, you will remember that we have tried it before and it didn't work. A quick recap: MLPs are generalized perceptrons, which are linear models that assume the output is some weighted sum of the input. They didn't work for some reason unknown when they were last tested back in January.

(Pictured: the disastrous performance in January)

It happened that on a random day in February I saw MLPs being used for weather forecasting (as a baseline against complicated deep learning stuff like GRU and LSTM) and had the idea of revisiting it. The MLPs so far were trained on the GPU using PyTorch and had a relatively "narrow" shape, i.e. the hidden layers had no more than 1024 neurons each. Repeating the experiment on a CPU with sklearn didn't get me anywhere either. The key change here was to favour breadth over depth. The logic was like this: The basic baseline dataset has 18 feature variables, and during our misadventures trying to win linear models' favour, it was noted that there are around 3000 degree-3 polynomial features that can be generated as combinations of these 18 guys. If the first hidden layer had around 3000 neurons, then each of them could capture (what would be roughly equivalent to) a polynomial feature. The next hidden layers would fish out useful ones, just like how PCA was used to cut the number down to 450. As such, a model with hidden layers 3072 -> 1024 -> 256 was created and trained on the CPU (because it was somewhat faster). This took around an hour and didn't generate many interesting diagrams, but at the end it gave an average f1-score of 0.64848 (n.b. other MLPs do not give anything above 0.5), which was surprisingly good. Some experimentation was done - because of the time it took, it had to be left overnight and gave zero interesting diagrams that could ostensibly have decorated this post to make it look prettier than Miss Hong Kong - and in the end I got a classifier model with hidden layers 3072 -> 1024 -> 1024 -> 1024 -> 256 that gave me 0.81633 average f1-score, which was already better than the sktime model. It is notable that the dataset used was the TSNV version, which would give more than 10,000 polynomial features instead of just 3000.
