(Pictured: the performance now, which is the exact opposite of a disaster)

While I just took the model as it was (come on, what else could I ask for?), I noted that it was totally possible to recreate it using PyTorch on the GPU. The documentation by sklearn has described in detail the implementation of the MLP and by copying those details I could make the model run on a GPU. I wasn't going to spend time on that because I was working on the experimental dataset at the same time, but it gave clear suggestions as to why the old PyTorch MLP failed so spectacularly - the settings might have assumed the MLP returns integers for scoring purposes, but turned out the MLP returned a floating point number instead. It is also possible to make a regressor instead of a classifier, but the regressors weren't just as good under the same configurations. So I opted for a classifier instead. So, that's it for today. Now we have a third working model (after XGBoost decision tree and sktime classifier) at our disposal. Next time we will revisit linear models, because, well, reasons.

item.title: Baseline Model (Part VIII): Linear Models Strike Back
item.dc:creator: fyp21028_admin
item.content:encoded:
Good day mates, let's get right into it. Last time we saw MLPs making a comeback; this time it will be linear models' turn.

Generalized Linear Models

Let us begin with a quick recap about linear models. They are, in essence, a mathematical equation linking our input features to the desired target using a weighted sum. To make them more useful, some additional wangjangling of the data can be done before they are fed to the models, such as calculating interaction terms, doing dimensionality reduction (via PCA) and computing kernels. A generic form of linear models is shown below: Y-hat stands for "predicted value", and it is a weighted sum of the inputs. This is sufficient for regression tasks, and for binary classifications, the output is further passed through a logistic function to get outputs in range 0-1. We can totally use other functions instead of the logistic. These functions, "inverse link functions", let us model more assumptions about the data, e.g. the weighted sum relates to the target through a logarithm. Further assumptions about the data could be included by specifying the distribution of the input data, so that if we made a mistake, we don't think about the difference between the right answer and the wrong attempt as a direct difference (like right - wrong), but rather as deviance of some distribution (more details here). This way, if the data has some Gaussian distribution, it can also be modelled properly. Combining deviances with (inverse) link functions, we get generalized linear models, which mathematically look like this: Where h stands for the inverse link function. We can move h to the left hand side and in that case, the word "inverse" is dropped. Generalized linear models are useful for our case because our data aren't linear (as shown by our earlier experiments, which failed spectacularly). Let us consider the look of some dummy data: The vertical axis y stands for the prediction target - probability of a TC strike - and the horizontal x some input feature, such as longitude. It is obvious that only some longitudes can possibly lead to positives, hence there is a big bulge in our dummy data. Fitting a straight line through the bulge will be a silly idea. If the data is transformed using polynomials to get interaction terms with other features, such as longitude times latitude, it is possible that the region corresponding to positives can be narrowed down, but it will still be linearly inseparable. How about kernels? Using the Nystroem kernel approximation algorithm, we can see how kernels transform our data.               Above are some examples. But it is still obvious that a straight line cannot be slapped onto any of the colourful lines. By assuming our bulge is more like a Gaussian distribution, then it is totally possible to use generalized linear models. But do they work? So I went ahead and implemented one. Noppity-nope, it doesn't. Generalized linear models were still not enough. That brings us to the next option.

Generalized Additive Models (GAMs)

As I was researching generalized linear models, I came across something called generalized additive models (GAMs). Mathematically they are formulated like this: With the link function on the left hand side (which doesn't really matter), it is basically the same as a generalized linear model, with one critical difference: Each feature x_i is put through some f before it is considered in the weighted sum. That f can be called a "term", which comes in a few flavours:
  • Spline terms: Using a number of basis functions, a curve (spline) is approximated and fitted to the data. The spline captures the relationship between x_i and y.
  • Tensor terms: Same as spline terms, except we can consider multiple input features in one go. The number of spline basis functions will increase exponentially.
  • Factor terms: The number of splines is dynamically determined, resulting in something that resembles a decision tree. Very computationally costly.
  • Linear terms also exist but we won't be using them.
Here is an example of a spline term being used:

(Image courtesy of pyGAM developers)

As you can see, the spline basis functions undergo different squishifications and approximate the hidden relationship. It is more than obvious that GAMs can handle our dummy data: Easy-peasy, melon-squeezy. The red dotted lines show a confidence interval whereas the blue line is the curve approximated from the data. GAMs can also take assumptions about the data's distribution and the right link function. Moreover, GAMs can be regularized to control overfitting, i.e. the model getting too good at doing the exercises (training data) and thus failing exams (validation/test data). An even better thing is, we can manually choose which features to give to the model and terms can be mixed and matched in any way, so tensors and splines can coexist and do their work independently. To build a GAM, a third-party Python package is needed, and pyGAM was chosen because it has good documentation.

GAMing Attempt 1: Using Original Data

Note: unless otherwise specified, the GAMs built were all linear GAMs, i.e. the data were assumed to have normal distribution and no link function was needed. Initially it didn't go very well. Even when giving 400 splines (basis functions) to each feature the average f1-score didn't manage to pass 0.5. Switching to the TSNV variant of the dataset (because the experimental dataset is also TSNV), which gave a 0.54243 average f1 on a logistic regression model, immediate improvement was observed and the average f1 reached 0.59. Using hundreds of splines became uneconomical at this point because it led to OOM errors, but this was good enough. I mean, look: This is way better than the rest of the linear models. A couple key observations were noted:
  • It really preferred to have all the input features at its disposal, dropping out things would require caution.
  • It can estimate the important/relevance of each feature, and apparently features corresponding to T=0h or T=-6h (6 hours ago) were the most informative.
  • Using tensor terms to recreate the spline-based models of HKWW didn't work and scores remained low.
  • 1000 splines would be needed to create a 3-feature tensor term, but the computation hardware could only take in 12-15 such terms before collapsing in an OOM. However, 12-15 interaction features were far from enough.
That means further feature selection and using polynomial features were both possible.

GAMing Attempt 2: Polynomial Feature Selection Using Trees

Work on GAMs originally stopped and attention was diverted to experimental models. By the time experimental GAMs started to work, I brought a couple useful techniques over and resumed work on the baseline GAM. This is the first of the useful methods: Because decision trees work well and fit quickly, they can be leveraged to filter polynomial features. The tens of thousands of polynomial features are all fed to a tree, and then we see which features are favoured by the tree, after that we only keep around 200 most informative ones. As we have already computed the polynomials in advance, there will be no need to use tensors to recreate them, and each selected feature can just be a regular spline term, which is memory efficient. After some testing, a slightly better score for the first predictand (minimal impact/TC warning signal no. 1) was obtained. However, the rest of the prediction targets could not be made better.

GAMing Attempt 3: Polynomial Feature Selection Using Mutual Information

Mutual information is another possible filtering method and we have actually discussed it in the past. In short, it identifies whether a feature correlates to the desired target in any way, which can be non-linear - not a problem since we would be using splines. However, mutual information is computationally intensive to calculate and a trade-off must be made. Therefore, only some of the input features were expanded into polynomials and then filtered. The chosen input features were those from T=-0h or T=-6h (first 13 or 26), because prior tests showed that they had the highest relevance. A large number of tests were made and it appeared that each predictand wanted some different settings:
  • Minimal impact: First 13 features in, best 300 polynomials out, 40 splines assigned to each.
  • Limited impact: Same but 20 splines would do.
  • Substantial impact: Same as limited impact, but just 200 polynomials would be enough.
  • Direct strike: First 13 features in, best 300 polynomials out, 20 splines assigned to each, and regularization must be cranked up a bit.
These gave an average f1-score of 0.64780, which was the best we could do. There has also been some consideration about alternative GAM choices - right now we assume things are normally distributed and there are no need for fancy link functions. Among the possible choices offered by pygam, only Poisson GAMs (Poisson dist., logarithm as link function) could possibly work, but when it came to building a model with performance comparable to linear GAMs, then Poisson GAMs were still insufficient.

item.title: Experimental Models (Part I): Tree-Based Models
item.dc:creator: fyp21028_admin
item.content:encoded:
Finally, it's time to start a new series. We are finally going to start working on experimental models that use the experimental dataset - baseline with dynamical meteorological data included, at the cost of losing 2/3 of dataset size - and test if our hypothesis works. The hypothesis is very important and we must constantly bear them in mind in this series:
If we include dynamical data in our data modelling, we can get a better performance because we also consider factors that change the TC's state, which in turn affect the warning signals/impact levels' state.
If you still remember the terminology from our time series modelling episode, you can further say this whole FYP's point is to see whether having the exogenous variables influencing our exogenous variables can improve performance, at least for the TC impact level forecasting problem. Let's also have a recap of what our dataset now contains:
  • From 1999 (ideally, but from 2008 in practice), for each TC in the Western North Pacific,
  • A number of 24-hour time series, each consisting of:
    • TC position (in polar coordinates), intensity, movement factors (i.e. exogenous variables, things that directly influence the following endogenous variables),
    • HKO TC warning signal statuses and whether we are suffering from a direct strike at the moment thanks to the TC in question, i.e. the four endogenous variables,
    • Environmental variables such as wind shear, humidity and temperature, i.e. the dynamical features exogenous to the exogenous variables.
  • There are 149 features per sample (full time series) and a total of 6955 samples.
Alright, let's dive right into it.

Tree-Based Model 1: XGBoost Classifier

The work on the baselines had greatly narrowed down the options available for the experimental models, so work on them were expected to be not time-consuming at all, which was indeed the truth. The smaller dataset meant that each model took only a sneeze's time to fit and a bazillion (OK I keep spelling it as "brazillion", damn) of them could be fitted in a short time. The first model to build was the good old XGBoost classifier, the most promising of them all. It fitted in a flash on default settings and had a whopping 0.92 average f1-score. I did take a moment to optimize the baseline XGBoost model so we could be very sure of where the ceiling of its performance could be, and that ceiling was 0.83. A quick comparison: On the left is the precision-recall curve of the baseline and the right is the experimental model. The optimal model puts the black dot right at the top right corner and you can see the experimental model almost nailed it perfectly. If you remember the past episodes, you might also remember the need to optimize decision thresholds (which was always done before the precision-recall curves were plotted) and to calibrate the probabilities. The latter tells how informative the returned probabilities are - our goal in the end is to build a probabilistic forecast. This is where things got slightly worrying: deliberate calibration seldom made things better by a noticeable margin, and with a small dataset it is easy to make inappropriate guesses. The calibration plot above shows that the guesses were somewhat OK (not too hideously far off from the perfect diagonal, like class 0) - but for the more complicated targets like direct strike (class 3) it is obvious that it would be the best to shift the line to the right a bit. Some optimization was done to make sure the performance ceiling was properly hit. The ceiling was 0.95791. While I was at it, I also did some calibration - perhaps it would work better this time - and ugh, there wasn't much improvement. But the orange line (class 3) did move to the right somewhat, which was favourable. And the above is the new calibration plot. It did make the curve for class 0 go a bit more wobbly, but for the sake of the ensemble forecast (where probabilities from multiple models get considered together) down the line, this would likely be necessary, so that the probabilities are comparable. There was also something fishy about the amazing performance. Let us look closely at the classification results: In this classification report, the precision, recall and f1-score values for all four predictands were computed. Notice how there were rather few "support" (positives in the validation data) - a quick check showed that only 11% of the data corresponds to positives, so for a dataset with 6955 samples among which some 9% was chosen for validation purposes (like, quizzes for the model), there would be just 6955 * 9% * 11% = 69 positives of any kind. Of course, categories overlap, but the number is still small. When the dataset is small, it might under-represent reality and even though our model could get things since 2008 right, the relative lack of outliers and irregularities could make us overconfident about the model's results, and it could totally work very poorly in the future. That is to say, a concern is "do our modelling techniques work better with smaller datasets?" If that is the case, then the comparisons with the baselines would become grossly unfair, even though both the baseline and experimental datasets have the same distribution (11% positives). This worry would soon be justified when other models were fitted.

Tree-Based Model 2: Extra Trees Classifier

Extra Trees Classifier is made of a bunch of highly randomized decision trees. It used to give decent-looking calibration plots (sensible probabilities) and had been quite successful predicting direct strikes, until the optimized XGBoost classifier outperformed it. It was able to fit very quickly too, so it was tested next to see whether it could still give a surprisingly good performance. And of course it did. The precision-recall curve was still very decent and the probability calibration out of the box was quite good. However, it didn't seem to like further optimization and the best results could be obtained with just the default settings, at 0.95075. The best baseline extra trees classifier had 0.79 f1-score for direct strike and now we had 0.97, but whether this was a blessing of the tininess of the dataset or not remained a big question.

Tree-Based Model 3: sktime Time Series Forest Classifier

This was the only working sktime model. It models time series directly, which is exactly what our data is like. It used to have a max performance at around 0.68-0.73, and this time it gave 0.87301 on default settings. Further optimization gave 0.88892. Let's see a couple more plots: The performance was still quite good - a significant improvement, not gonna like, just like Russia after Stalin put his industrialization plans through - and we didn't starve the people like Stalin did, we got some satisfactory probabilities. I think this should be it for now. Next time, we will move over to linear models, make another Gaussian process attempt (spoiler alert: again it refused to work), and start wrestling MLPs. The issue that models might just work better with fewer data would also be addressed in due course.

item.title: Experimental Models (Part II): Gaussian Processes and Linear Models
item.dc:creator: fyp21028_admin
item.content:encoded:
Welcome to the second episode of our experimental models series. This time we will go through Gaussian processes (GPs) and linear models (GAMs mainly).

Gaussian Processes Take 2

Remember our Gaussian process misadventure last time? It didn't work because of quite a variety of plausible reasons and this time, just for the sake of doing it, I tried it again. The smaller dataset size allows for exact GPs, instead of approximated GPs we used last time in order to avoid eating up the entirety of our available memory. Scikit-learn comes with support for exact GPs and different kernel (covariance) combinations. A GP classifier was built and whatever configurations that finished running in reasonable time claimed "100% accuracy" on the training data but exactly zero accuracy on validation data. When the produced probabilities were checked, the reason was revealed: it kept predicting "0.5", which meant the positives were treated as anomalies (noise) or the model managed to only learn the average between positives (1) and negatives (0). So, without any need to show you pictures, it can be concluded that GPs will definitely not work.

Linear Models Again - Logits, Regressors, Kernels and KNN

The tests with baseline models yielded a small list of workable linear models. They were simply tried again on the new data. So, TLDR: there was some improvement but really not too much.
  • Logistic regression: it worked a bit and gave an average f1-score just south of 0.6.
  • Linear regression: practically the same.
  • K-neighbours regressor: better (score around 0.65), but impractical - of course we can just consider the two most similar samples to make a prediction, but that is not enough for more anomalous cases.
  • With Nystroem-approximated polynomial kernel: score 0.56, better than before (below 0.5).
  • PCA with polynomial features for feature selection: impractical due to the number of polynomials generated exceeds 100,000.
  • MARS (TM): technical incompatibilities exist, but it can be guessed that the scores would be better than the 0.54 it used to give.
Let's see a couple illustrations: Logits, before (left) and after (right).

Linear Models: GAM and Pain

Generalized additional models (GAMs) introduced last time (I guess) showed decent performance and scores around 0.6 were achieved just on the baseline dataset. This time it got even better and actually started overfitting - worked well with training data but not so on held out validation data. Linear GAMs gave scores comfortably above 0.6 out of the box, and Poisson GAMs could even reach 0.76; the previously tested trick of extracting useful polynomial features from a decision tree was tried again but to no avail (presumably because there were outright too many polynomial features the tree had to handle). Most breakthrough came from using mutual information to extract the best polynomials generated from the first couple time steps' features, so that the GAM down the line could achieve scores around 0.8, which were very compelling for linear models. To reiterate myself again, this is how the trick worked:
  • The dataset is just a 24-h time series. The first two time steps, corresponding to "right now" and "6 hours ago", were selected (the latter time step being optional).
  • Polynomial features were generated from these guys and then fed to mutual information.
  • The most relevant ones were chosen. There were around 100-200 of these guys, and beyond this number the performance started going down.
  • Build GAMs out of them.
This whole procedure was time-consuming because each GAM would take between 5 and 45 minutes to fit and we needed four of them, one for each predictand. The time cost grew even higher when parameters were explored to find better combinations. For example, effort had to be made to confirm the number of relevant features to choose, the regularization strength (which controlled whether Poisson GAMs were willing to cooperate), and the number of spline basis functions to assign to each feature. After some nasty testing and a lot of waiting, the best combinations were found:
  1. Linear GAM, top K=137 features generated from the N=1st time step, 60 splines for minimal impact
  2. Poisson GAM, K=137, N=1, interaction terms only (no X*X*X), 20 splines for limited impact
  3. Linear GAM, K=137, N=1, 40 splines, regularization lambda=6.0 for substantial impact
  4. Linear GAM, K=137, N=1, interaction only, 60 splines for direct strike
The score was 0.79 which was okay, but the calibration wasn't. The Brier scores were only average (because all other models easily achieved something an order of magnitude lower), and the graph shows that most of the time the model predicted probabilities of around 0.5, which was silly (once again, average guessing). The worst part was that due to how GAMs were only partly compatible with scikit-learn, performing probability calibration would be technically near impossible. This left MLP as the only hope (except it wasn't good enough to act as one). We will get to that very soon, so please stay tuned.

item.title: Project Exhibition
item.dc:creator: fyp21028_admin
item.content:encoded:
Hello there. It's been a while since I last posted (I was finishing up the project's formalities) but I'm most happy to announce that this final year project has finished! Here, take a look at the poster: Of all things, this is a square JPEG. Also see our project demo: [video width="1920" height="1080" mp4="https://wp.cs.hku.hk/2021/fyp21028/wp-content/uploads/sites/192/3min-presentation.mp4"][/video] The source code is available on GitHub. Owing to file size limits, the models were not completely uploaded (they ended up being on Google Drive and Mega, tell me if you need Pixeldrain and Zippyshare and even BT links) and some of the big files were stored using Git LFS (which means when the files are downloaded, you would get a link to that file instead), so the code you can download will be incomplete. All the reports of the project are also included in the repository. Repository updates to be carried out include:
  • Upload the poster and the demo video one way or another.
  • Find a way to export this website so that it would survive time.
  • Include my email correspondences with supervisor Dr Beta Yip, which include some Q&A that might interest you.
For now, that's all. The rest of this blog will finish updating soon. Thanks and bye-bye!

item.title: Baseline Models (Extra Post): Downsizing the Dataset
item.dc:creator: fyp21028_admin
item.content:encoded:
Bonjour, c'est un(e? I don't speak baguette) additional post on baseline models and datasets. You see, last time we got very solid results with GAMs and trees which were rather disproportionate - the scores about 0.9 were screaming that they were the outcome of overfitting. This created a new issue: could it be the models were simply better at dealing with the smaller dataset? The baseline TSNV was still around 45000 samples big but the experimental dataset was only 6500. This indicates an unforeseen issue: the dataset sizes should equal, otherwise there would be one more variable getting in the way of our analyses.

Downsizing the baseline dataset

So I got to work. The idea was to cut out most records in the baseline TSNV dataset. While a random sampling was possible, it could be unfair to the experimental dataset which represented data since 2008 (mostly) - the baseline included data going back to the 1950s iirc. Therefore, all baseline data before 2008 were to be trimmed off. This involved going back to the IBTrACS data, because the merged TSNV dataset did not include year information (so that we could just cut stuff off from there). Building a new smaller baseline dataset was simple, though, because the old code could be copy-and-pasted. 2008 was a perfect cutoff, too - the resultant dataset had 6957 samples, while the experimental dataset had 6955. Close enough, I'd say. Interestingly, the number of positives of any kind (and in any combinations) is roughly consistent (11%) in all datasets, so random sampling might have also worked. My, I'm getting unenthusiastic at writing this. Let's quickly blast through the rest.

Rebuilding Models

Now that the dataset was different (again), the models had to be rebuilt (again). As the work on experimental models was well underway, only models that would be used in comparisons were rebuilt. Once more, copy-and-pasting was the main technique used. Some of you may be smart enough to note the repeating patterns in the code that could be simplified using functional programming techniques, but because imports and jupyter notebooks work in a mildly infuriating way when combined with the folder structures, I gave up on that and went for whatever was the fastest (but not the easiest to maintain and keep consistent). Some key observations were made when comparing the models to the experimental ones:
  • The worry was right, the margin between baseline and experimental models had diminished. For tree-based models (XGBoost), the margin is as small as 0.01 average F1 score.
  • But the experimentals were consistently better. That meant the theory "statistical-dynamical is better" is sound and valid.
  • Calibration was mostly unnecessary. This was become a big issue, since good calibration implied useful ensemble predictions down the line.
  • MLPs were extra annoying, because when the dataset size decreased, the batch size had to go down accordingly, but it was hard to replicate the approx. 0.8 average f1 score the full baseline dataset had. That suggests that MLPs prefer to have more data.
  • Overfitting was mild for everybody (because hyperparameter optimization was quite possible) except the MLPs, each of which took 4+ hours to fit - optimization would take centuries.
In any case, a big flaw had been patched. Two more posts and we will finish our talk on experimental models - one on MLPs, one on yet another flaw, then we'll be talking about ensembles. Just 3 posts, hopefully not too much for me to write. If you think this post was probably written in a hurry, you are almost right on the money. These tests were conducted some 5-7 days before the FYP final report was handed in, and arguably all the final results included were obtained within this one-week window. There wasn't enough time to consolidate and remember all the useful details that would come in handy when writing blog posts. Sorry for the short post - I will expand on this (perhaps, these promises tend to be unfulfilled, you have been warned) if I have time and remember more details later. But, gorblimey, the work on the downsized dataset did go by like a blast, or to fit the topic of this project, go by like a typhoon crossing Japan at 100kmph (not wind speed, but translation speed).

item.title: Experimental Models (Part III): MLPs and Pain
item.dc:creator: fyp21028_admin
item.content:encoded: Welcome back and happy Walpurgis Night! This time we will finish our talk on experimental models (almost). Back then the main source of pain was with linear models: GAMs didn't quite work out, until we tried to generate (a subset of all possible) polynomial features and use mutual information to select some from them, but each model took anywhere between 10 and 40 minutes to finish fitting; and before that the initial source of pain was MLPs because they did not fit, even if we switched over to sklearn it didn't work well either, until a radical change in network structure was carried out. This pain would strike again in the final weeks of the project, alongside much more minor aches such as the weird input data format requirements of sktime (hopefully covered before, the gist is that for some reason the format did not support cross validation well, so hyperparameter optimization was occasionally prone to failures). Initial misadventures up to 7 April were essentially just unsuccessful attempts to find a workable model structure that could fit to the now much smaller dataset. The older configurations did not work, nor did newly invented ones. The best scores were around 0.58 - remember the old baseline MLP could get 0.83 or so - which were as bad as a spoiled potato. The key problem here was batch size: the algorithm used to optimize the MLP from the inside uses batches of samples from the input dataset to infer the loss values and how to make them suck less. With a significantly downsized dataset, the batch size should, logically, go down as well, because now the intricacies of the data would easily be overlooked with large batches. A secondary problem was network structure, because there are no simple rules-of-thumb to decide that - some people say 1 layer is enough, some people say successive layers should be half the size of the previous, etc. Trial and error was the only way that would lead to success. Therefore, a long nasty battle commenced, with the objective being to first find the best batch size and then the best network configuration. The batch size was chosen to be 32 - a far cry from the old value of 512 - and then it was found that four layers would likely suffice. Each model took hours to fit, and given that it was already April, that meant time was pressing and there was no time to thoroughly check everything (e.g. whether extra regularization would be good). In any case, the best configuration was (3072, 2048, 1024, 256) which also differed a lot from the baseline (3072, 1024, 1024, 1024, 256). Five- or six-layer configurations were under-tested but the initial results suggested that they probably won't work with the experimental data. It's been a while since we looked at diagrams, so here are some (you can see them on GitHub!): The precision-recall curve was just average. The red warning saying "division encountered problems" is typically a bad sign (that were often encountered working with sktime and linear models), indicating that there were invalid values (such as division by zero) in the F1 score calculation process. Good models never had these - so conversely it can be said that the MLP sucks somewhat, but not too much (like a mosquito sucking vs a roomba sucking). The Brier scores were higher than average (which wasn't good) and although the blue line was quite well-calibrated, the orange line wasn't. It suggests that the model did not predict anything above 0.45, which was not desirable - no way in Detroit would that be a proper guess. MLPs generally show better calibration when more data are supplied, but we no have enough data. As always, extra calibration was a silly idea. The limited amount of validation data and the number of cross validation folds (problem: this wasn't ever done, since cross validation involves fitting the model again. Like Halifax we'd have that American time) made the extra calibration work poorly. The F1 scores obtained were also lower than the baselines - better than the downsampled one, of course, but not as good as the one that got to work with the full baseline dataset. That is because the number of data samples available decreased. Speaking of baselines, the experiences obtained running into dead ends here were reused to fit downsampled MLPs, even though it remained time-consuming and disappointing. I think the hurriedly obtained experiment results would be prone to future flak, but probably no one would want to scrutinize this. In any case, there was far from enough time to better optimize stuff. For instance, these MLPs (even for baselines) overfitted on the dataset, so they worked splendidly on the training data but not validation/testing data. To fix this, reducing the model size (effect not obvious) and increasing regularization strength (limits the complexity of the model) are possible solutions, but very little time was available for the fine-tuning of the latter (imagine the amount of precious CPU time this would need: each candidate regularization strength value would be used to fit three models, each on a different split/subset of the training data, and evaluated on the rest to confirm its performance). So, in short, with the dataset change, the MLP must be re-configured from scratch and that was not a very severe problem, except we didn't have the time to do so. That's it for now. Next time, we will discuss a major pitfall that we ran into.

item.title: Experimental Models (Part IV): Regressors and Mistakes
item.dc:creator: fyp21028_admin
item.content:encoded:
Hi. My name is Vikram Rahul Abishek Pranav Rajesh and welcome to yet another insignificant machine learning tutorial. In today's episode we will be answering an obvious question about the elephant in the room: most of our models are classifiers (except GAM), why?
Classification vs Regression for this Project
The problem this project tries to solve involves finding a probability. There are two ways to do this: Firstly, we can use regression models that spit out continuous outputs and treat that output as the probability (but there's a catch); secondly, we can alternatively use classifiers that happen to spit out class probabilities (probabilistic classification) and call it a day, but there's another catch (the probabilities should be well calibrated). So far, we have been constantly favouring the latter. Ever since the initial tests with XGBoost started with classifiers for some reason unknown (so was the PyTorch MLP, I think this was because the previous time I worked with machine learning my group solved a classification problem instead of a probabilistic classification problem) and I found the regressors seemed to work just as fine as the classifiers (but calibration was not checked!), I stopped bothering with regressors. The reasons to favour probabilistic classification (may have) included:
  • It was a headache to write extra testing code for the regressors.
    • This led to the aforementioned "catch", see below
  • I was already behind schedule, so I might as well stick to the classifiers.
  • It happened that classifiers were a hair better.
    • And, as an afterthought, there is already something called probabilistic classification on Wikipedia, maybe that's the way to go.
But over time, regressor code was written and I got ever more behind schedule. Nonetheless, I did not back to see if the tree-based and time series model would work as regressors. Funny enough, the first batch of baseline MLPs actually included MLP regressors, but then I focused on MLP classifiers instead. Later on in the project, I supposed that classifiers were simply easier to build and manage, which was a sloppy excuse however you look at it. A better excuse is that regressors may lead to some loss of information.
The Information Loss Argument
Regressors produce continuous outputs naturally while classifiers produce discrete ones. However, there is typically no bounds as to what kind of numbers a regressor may give you. In our case, we want numbers between 0 and 1 (inclusive), but there is no guarantee for that and extra attention must be paid. Logistic regression, one of the simplest linear classifier out there (see here), fixes this by (arguably) fitted a curve instead of a straight line to the data, with the curve being bound in the range 0-1. (Pictured: logistic function and linear regression, images are public domain and from Wikimedia Commons) The red line of linear regression can extend indefinitely but the logistic function will limit outputs in 0-1. To achieve classification (for both cases, really), one simply finds a decision threshold to separate negatives from positives. For regression models that do not incorporate decisions within them (that makes them classifiers instead, you know), something has to be done to handle values <0 or >1. The solution in the past (glossed over in the post) was to pass them through a sigmoid function (which looks like the logistic function actually), so the results would not be out of bounds. Fun fact: arguably, passing probabilistic calibration results through an extra logistic regression can achieve calibration. There is an alternative though, which is to simply discard numbers out of bounds and replace them with the nearest legitimate number (-1 => 1, 1.5 => 1.0). This latter method is called clipping. The problem with this sort of adjustment is that some information is lost - the value before and after the transformation may not carry the same meaning, i.e. the adjustment distorts the meaning of the predicted value. This does not happen to classifiers, so they may be more suitable. Of course, this is a sloppy argument still because we have to define meaning in the first place, but the choice of adjustment method did create issues later on. Before we proceed, here's a quick aside: Some may argue that out-of-bounds value indicates misfits, i.e. a good regressor should be able to return values in desired intervals at all times if it fitted to the data perfectly. This is incorrect, however, because unseen data may lead to unexpected outputs. For examples, typhoons in December are anomalous, so the corresponding "probability" produced might end up being negative where it shouldn't. Thus, ideal regression models would still have this out-of-bounds problem.
The Breakthrough (Kinda): Clip > Sigmoid
The thing that put regressors on the table again was GAM (of course). The calibration plots of the GAMs looked terrible: Pictured is the calibration performance of the experimental GAM using sigmoid adjustment. The model apparently did not predict anything outside of the small range of 0.35-0.75. Although the model still made sound predictions when a decision threshold was added, this was far from optimal because the poor calibration meant it would be useless in the ensemble (too biased input probabilities). Switching to clipping adjustment, magic happened: Look at that blue line, the probabilities for minimal impact were actually perfectly calibrated! The line for class 3 (direct strike) was still average, but it had greatly improved. Better still, the decision thresholds barely changed (this was the magical part - sigmoid and clipping should be much different) and the classification scores obtained did not change. This made me go back and fit all GAMs (baseline and experimental alike) with clipping adjustment. GAMs had been very consistent - same setting and the model fits to the exact same state and produces the same probabilities - and no changes would be needed (except to use clipping adjustment). This allowed the GAM's entry to the future ensemble and created a brand new problem.
Fitting Regression Models All Over Again
This breakthrough took place some seven days before the final report was due. The success of the GAM as a regression model implied that it was likely that the other modelling techniques used (trees, sktime, MLP and even GP) would also work as regressors - after all, a compelling argument against regressors were needed. And so I went back to fitting everything as regressors, for both baseline and experimental datasets. As always, with the small dataset, models fitted quickly (except the MLPs). The following observations were made:
  • Regression models, when compared to classifiers, occasionally had better calibration.
  • Classification (deterministic forecast) performances were also close.
    • The baseline XGBoost regressor had an F1 score of 0.90 which was the best among baselines (remember, baseline XGBoost classifiers had scores of around 0.87), and set a very high standard for experimental models.
  • Gaussian processes (GPs) still refused to work. Understandable.
  • MLPs were extra tricky.
An example of regression models showing decent calibration is as follows: First picture: classifier, second: regressor. Class 0 actually showed some improvement because the line was now more of a smooth curve and the over-forecasting (the line living under the diagonal) was reduced. Class 3 was slightly smoother, but no values above 0.75 were predicted which was a drawback.
MLP Regressors
With MLPs, things got extreme. With the same settings, the experimental MLP regressor had a pathetic F1 score of 0.14. The training loss was very low, however - the mean square error of the predictions was well below 0.01. That meant the MLP regressor had overfitted and a smaller network/a lot of regularization/more data would do the trick. While time was lacking (7 days) so no fine testing could be done, this showed a potential problem: For neural networks (MLPs), regression seemed to be a simpler problem than classification. In practice, the neural networks were the same in all regards, it was the error metric that differed. For regression, the distance between the correct value and the predicted value is calculated (mean square error); whereas for classification, how much the predictions favour wrong classes is measured as well (log loss). The difference may (or may not) be subtle, but the model behaviour changes a lot because of that. The experimental MLPs' 0.75 vs 0.14 margin was an overexaggeration, but extra data would not have helped much. With the 45000 baseline samples, the models showed a performance margin of about 0.2 (rounded down), while 6500 baseline samples gave a margin of 0.1. In conclusion, regressing the probabilities must have been a simpler task for the MLPs and to obtain a working MLP regressor one must painstakingly and patiently further adjust the parameters, if not from scratch.
Conclusion
The consideration that regression models would not solve the TC forecasting problem better than classifiers had been proven largely invalid, and more work could be/could have been done on regression models. The experiments, hastily done (the MLPs were not thoroughly tested), had added new candidates to the ensemble arsenal. The sloppiness and rushed nature of this project's work - most of which effectively done in the last fortnight - are suboptimal and I hope someone would deal with it in the future (ahem). Although I nichten-lichten it, I had to go along with it, and thus there is this project report you see on the pinned post (as of now). Next time, we would consolidate on our results and build, at last, the promised ensemble forecast.

item.title: Final Ensemble and Concluding Remarks
item.dc:creator: fyp21028_admin
item.content:encoded:
Happy 40th anniversary of Akina Nakamori's first single (it was yesterday) and welcome to the final (hooooopefully) episode of our project blogs! Today we'll finish up by going through the final ensemble forecaster and reviewing what mess we have done.

Statistical-Dynamical Forecast vs Traditional Approaches

The goals of the project were just occasionally stated, but the two objectives of this project are to
  1. Develop an ensemble statistical-dynamical forecaster to assess TC impact level probabilities for Hong Kong
  2. Confirm the statistical-dynamical approach is legit, else (1) won't work
If you remember what have been stated in the past, you know there are some discrepancies:
  • The original plan was to "explore the ways to evaluate the probabilities of a TC affecting HK and the corresponding extent of impact".
    • "Explore the ways": done
    • Ensembles were not really mentioned (but was in the project plan).
    • Rephrase the second half to "assess TC impact level probabilities" and it will be ok
    • Notably, the terms "strike probability" and "impact level probability" were used interchangeably. Of course, the latter is more accurate.
Have we achieved any objectives? The answer is positive. Let's begin with the second. Over the previous blogs, we have built a baseline dataset and an experimental dataset, which only differed in the predictor variables present, and a number of corresponding models to gauge their respective performances. The scores of the experimental models have not been exactly presented so far, so here's an overview:
Model Baseline model score Experimental model score
XGBoost Classifier 0.86735 0.92765
XGBoost Regressor 0.90432 0.87246
Extra Trees Classifier 0.88469 0.89849
Extra Trees Regressor 0.89117 0.89823
GAM 0.75851 0.81090
Time Series Forest Classifier 0.73426 0.81236
Time Series Forecast Regressor 0.73471 0.72107
MLP Classifier 0.69481 0.74856
MLP Regressor 0.58692 0.14684
Remember the metric here is the F1 score, averaged across all four predictands - minimal, limited and substantial impact (levels) plus direct strike. The key takeaways include:
  • The experimental models worked better than baselines in general (objective 2 secured)
  • Classifiers are generally quite similar to regressors in terms of performance (see here)
  • The exact scores attainable depend on the model type
Another useful thing to recall is the forecasting product by HKWW. It predicts the probabilities of the HKO hoisting a certain TC warning signal (which is the same as 2/4 predictands of ours, we merged signals 8-10 in the 3rd one), forecasts valid for 6 hours (extensible to arbitrary windows ahead, because their forecast depends on TC position and intensity forecasts - which are out of scope for us). They used something like GAMs (can't tell, their docs didn't say anything in detail) to analyze best track and HKO warnings data and achieved an average F1 score of 0.845 (assuming their numbers are trustworthy - they said nothing about calibration and decision thresholds), which our tree-based models easily pwned. This shows that, to a pretty fair extent, our statistical-dynamical approach is indeed better than their relatively traditional method. A further improvement to the scores above and our edge over HKWW is to introduce an ensemble, so that we complete objective one. In the closing days of the project (before the final report submission deadline, that is), the ensemble was properly built. Let's move on to the relevant details.

The Ensemble: Stacking Regressor

Let's not move on just yet, here's the aforementioned first single by Akina Nakamori. Clicked? Right, let's go. Among the experimental models listed in the table above, the MLP regressor was removed (of course) and because there were minor benefits, the time series forest classifier was calibrated, then all those models were admitted to the ensemble. Some tests were made and it was found that the more ensemble members there were, the better the performance would be. Now that the ensemble members were selected, the natural next step was to find a way to balance their outputs to make a final forecast, that should be more robust and comprehensive than any individual member's. The obvious solution was to use a weighted sum, like linear models do, but this leaves a couple questions open:
  • How to find the best weights? Should the average F1 score be normalized and used as the weight, so better models have a stronger influence?
  • Are we doing regression or classification then? How to deal with out-of-bound outputs? (This question was an afterthought)
Leaving the second question open, the first one can be easily answered. To optimize the output probabilities given the inputs, it was evident that a linear regressor could be used to avoid the heavy lifting of calculating the best weights. Similarly, a new model could be asked to classify the input probabilities as "yes" and "no", then the class probabilities would be found. This method of adding an extra model to act as the ensemble voting mechanism is called stacking. Scikit-learn provides stacking method support, but its implementation involves fitting the member models again, which was out of the question because we were pressed on time. The stacked model would be developed manually. The following options for the stacked model were considered:
  • Linear regression: Very good, but looked like it overfitted.
  • ElasticNet regression: linear regression with a lot of regularization, but it didn't work (see GitHub).
  • Logistic regression: Fair, but the decision thresholds were far away from 0.5, indicating subpar calibration.
  • Extra Trees classifier: Bad calibration, mediocre scores, as disappointing as the 2012 new mix of Akina Nakamori's second single which had the motion and energy taken out of it.
  • Generalized linear model: The output variable can be assumed to be of other distibutions, but it didn't work.
  • Ridge regression: linear regression with some regularization to control overfitting, attained the best balance.
To give you a picture of how good the linear regressor had become, here's a picture: Very fishy, innit? The 1.0 F1 scores were screaming of overfitting because it could totally be a fluke, as we didn't have many samples. The calibration also looked meh. This time, all four classes were plotted, and the lines showed that the predicted values were clustered around 0 and 1 (which is something the ideal model would do - always predict 0 and 1's and always getting them right), with some bias shifting around where the 0.5 should be. With regularization introduced, it would be possible to adjust the shapes of these lines to get a less biased model and get better performances in the future. This is what the ridge regressor did without adjustments: The scores were lower than linear regression but still quite suspicious. Quite similar to linear regression. At least the line for class 3 was closer to the diagonal. And this is what happened when some regularization was applied: Not much difference, you may say, and the scores went down. I'd say I gave up fighting overfitting by this point, but the new calibration plots were something I'd gladly take: I suppose this was much better. Therefore, this version of the ridge regressor was accepted as the final ensemble model.

Operational Forecasts, Demo, and Future Improvements

While objective one may be said to be done by this point, it would be better if some code could be written so someone could use the models to make forecasts of actual TCs. I attempted a speedrun at that and obtained some results (here) and the 3-min demo video (here) should give you a good picture of how the thing should be used. Now we can call objective one and all the project done. Rejoice! At least that's what I've said to myself. There are still some areas of improvement that need to be addressed someday. These include:
  • The operational forecast notebooks lack usability. Any user will have to go into the source code and run it block by block. Moreover, the input and retrieval of TC/dynamical data are still inconvenient.
  • The ensemble is still overfitted. A more realistic F1 score would be about 0.85-0.92, but there are no ways to ascertain that.
    • Unless we obtain more data - the tiny 6500 (or is it 6900? I forgot, but it's unimportant) dataset only contains data from the last 15 years or so (not even). More data means we can cover more intricacies and enjoy more suffering fitting better models.
  • More work on regressors, especially MLP regressors, should be done, so that their potential could be best leveraged.
  • There has to be more forecasting methods out there. And someone must have the insight as to why GPs sucked.
  • The most useful predictors (according to the models) are listed in the project report, but I don't know how to make sense of them. Professional meteorologists will be needed to help filter out useless stuff for future datasets/models.
  • The definitions of the impact levels are sloppy: they are only tied to HKO warning signals, which we all know are very inappropriate measurements of TC impact. A better impact level index should be devised in the future, but it's easier said than done.
  • The project blog losing quality over time: The latest posts have been short, agrammatical and lacking in jokes.
I think that's all for this project and all that I have to say about it. Special thanks to Dr CL Yip for being the attentive supervisor, Dr YK Choi for the COMP4802 Extended Final Year Project arrangement, Dr PW Li of the HKO, online folks such as ILmao, Ryou and Avi in Avi's Discord server, and of course, the (hopefully not imaginary) you reading this post.
